description:
This is a gem in the heart of The City 
Open to the public, and it's very very free! 
So much culture along this long street 
Filled with murals created by the artistic elites
A million photo ops for those who #DoItForTheGram
Even MJ strutting his moves - rockin' my favorite jam 
There are eyes that watch your every move 
But don't worry, just be yourself - you ain't got nothing to prove 
Remember it's still an alley, so be careful 
Or you'll find yourself at odds with a semblance of the devil.
author: Thuy N.

description:
The murals here are nicely done.

Very short stroll through this alley.  

Not sure I'd go out of my way for this one though
author: Liz K.

description: This alley has so much to offer. Just stroll and pay attention and appreciate the art that surrounds you.
author: Tashawa W.

description: Nice murals along the alley, the artists repaint them from time to time. It's always great to come back after few months to see the new murals. Love the details. Go there during day time when there are more people, be careful if you are alone at the alley.
author: Choy T.

description: Murals all around,  definitely lots to take in.  Make sure you go through the alley ways because art is everywhere.
author: Christie I.

description:
Art was really cool and pictureworthy, but there were some pretty scummy people lingering around in the surrounding neighborhoods and by a park that was close by that made my girlfriend feel a little uncomfortable as we walked. One of the cars we walked by before entering the alley also had a busted window, so those few negatives left a less than perfect image of the area. 
I never personally felt anything less than content but I would say 3.5 stars as a result. We ate at la taqueria which was right around the corner right before coming here which was hella bomb
author: Rick C.

description: Nice to see art in different ways. Very strong messages here. After tacos we take a stroll here. Highly recommend this place it makes you think of the reality that we are living.
author: Isaiah G.

description:
The quality of the art here is mostly very good. Some of the stuff is not as great. Most of the art reflects the story of the Mission District but also that of Mexicans/Chicanos and even Latinos in general. The issues expressed here are also universal among disenfranchised communities of all kinds. The art is very colorful. Balmy Alley is not far from Galeria de la Raza. In my opinion Balmy Alley is better than Clarion Alley and it is also less crowded so you get better picture opportunities. If you're lucky you'll get to meet on of the friendlier locals that we met there and get the low down on the art and local history and culture. Parking is tough around here.

What can I do without at Balmy Alley?
Nothing.

What stands out at Balmy Alley?
The fact that it represents a culture which may or may not be your own faithfully. With an open mind you will see it is well worth your time.

Five stars!!!! Balmy Alley is really, really ridiculously cool!!!!
author: Miguel R.

description: Famous fabulus - go there - check out my pics!  How amazing all these artists and now they are making it an even lovelier street adding plants.  Many local people contribute to this.  It's amazing!  And there are many more incredible murals all over this area - get a map, take your camera and enjoy!
author: Tina O.

description: Tough to park but well worth the effort to see all the artwork along the street.  There is a clean restroom at Garfield Square and it is patrolled by the local police. Does not take long to see most all of the murals
author: Maxine D.

description:
Cool street art but all the 5 star reviews made me expect more. Balmy's paintings are mostly on fences and garage doors and they are about social issues that affect the Mission and its residents. It only takes about 5 minutes to see it and the street is in a quieter part of the Mission.

I appreciate this art and the fact that it's not super-touristy. However, based on quality/quantity of paintings, I'd recommend Clarion.
author: Yi Z.

description:
This short Street is an out door musium if murals.  There is everything from memorials to Where the Wild Things Are.   It's kind of amazing.   There are lots of murals on most of the homes/garages but there are breaks, lots of plants.  A lot of work and planning must have gone into each one.   It was exiting to get to see it all.

It's a bit out of the way.  But close enough that I walked in and out.   I will be back.
author: Mark B.

description: This was my first time going to Balmy Alley and it was worth the short walk from Mission St. I would give it 5 stars, but I felt that there should've been more to see and was a little disappointment. Balmy Alley is a block filled with colorful, captivating, detailed murals mainly showcasing local gentrification and human rights. The alley is located in the much quieter area of the Mission surrounded by small shops and hole in the wall restaurants. I do hope to see newer artwork in the future. In the meantime, I encourage people to check it out.
author: Crystal T.

description:
An alley worth seeing. 

The Mission is going thru a lot of changes - some bad, some good. With the gentrification that is currently ongoing throughout the city, this neighborhood is in the epicenter of it all. Look no further than what is going on in Dolores Park a few blocks away from this alley. 

You have the rich techies and the I'm-better-than-you-attitude hipsters who have migrated in this neighborhood and priced out the locals who were and are still the backbones of the city. These are hard-working middle class citizens who can no longer afford a rent in this neighborhood, nor the city. The park has been run over by thugs and hoodlums every weekend and leaves a wake of devastation behind every single time. These people have no respect for the history, authority, culture, environment and diversity of the city and all act entitled simply because they can afford a 3K - 5K rent to live in this neighborhood. 

Yup, the park has become the landfill of the privileged. Check out the video on this link:  http://kron4.com/2015/03/24/video-shows-uphill-battle-to-keep-dolores-park-clean/

Why is this rant relevant to this review, you may ask?

Well, some of the murals on Balmy Alley depicts that; however, just like the diverse city that is San Francisco, it is and so much more. This is just one part of the story, but all are connected with different artworks and artists all collaborating to tell their story and our story. The Mission is the mecca of murals and Balmy Alley is solely devoted to giving the artists a canvas to express themselves. A place to be seen and heard: sometimes more powerful than the spoken word. 

The talents behind these murals are like our conscience just to remind us that these are constantly playing out and have an impact on all of us whether directly or indirectly. All of the murals are organically created with the freedom one might not be afforded with if it were to be exhibited in a museum or a gallery. There are no restraints with each brush stroke and paint stroke, and that is the beauty in every single piece. All are unique, and each one special with a distinct story to tell from whimsical to political. Just like the city, a cornucopia of artwork and very diverse.
author: John G.

description:
San Franciso is pretty much mural central. You can find them just about any and everywhere. 

This tiny block is pretty substantial for a number of reasons:

1. The block is short. Like, shorter than a standard city block it seems. 

2. Apparently this is the most concentrated collection of murals in the city. 

3. It's wildly visual! Stunning. Every single piece of the walls and garage doors are filled with color and sometimes covered with adornments. 

4. The block carries a crucially important historic and contemporary statement, drawing attention to anger over human rights and other abuses throughout Central America. 

It is a visually striking and emotionally overwhelming tapestry, with a crucial narrative. Also, the murals apparently change time to time. And you can reach out to Precita Eyes for a guided tour.   

Highly recommended stop, even if you are just passing through the area. You can walk it, or drive it one way.
author: Monica E.

description: Stumbled upon Balmy Alley while grabbing lunch in the Mission. Low key, beautiful short walk, highlighting the history of Mission. I was there on a rainy Easter Sunday and was fortunate to have the space to myself. Wonderful place to check out when in the area.
author: Masha K.

description:
I love this street!  It is the most ironic place I have ever had the pleasure of strolling through.  The walls are filled with beautiful murals with veiled (some not so veiled) messages about gentrification, greed, money, techies, struggles, and white people and the street is filled with the subjects of these murals.  

It is something to see....
author: Melissa R.

description:
It's amazing how the murals are integrated in this alley with the surrounding infrastructure of gates, fences, portals, homes, garages, shops, etc. We were lucky to see some of what's behind the "decorated walls." It was also neat to see the correlation between the Native American culture we learned about on our walking tour earlier during our visit. 

I think I photographed each and every part of this alley, and luckily for you (Yano - if you read this) I didn't see any vandalism which needs to be removed. :) 

PS - @Yano - thanks for recommending!
author: Ronit M.

description:
Balmy Street - the alley lined with murals, many complaining about hipsters and gentrification, which is then filled with hipsters and gentrifiers taking selfies in the alley of themselves in front of said murals. What's not to love!? Irony at its finest. If you're iron deficient, you've gotta check this out. 

I've taken my 88 year old grandma to check out these murals, I've taken a 12 year old cousin who loves Starbucks more than Philz coffee to these murals, I've taken first dates to these murals, and I've taken stoned friends here as well. This collection of humanity is as eclectic as the smatterings of paint in this alley, and they all loved it. 

It's art freed to the streets.  24th also makes for an easy walking tour with Humphry Slocombe and taquerias aplenty.
author: Erik L.

description:
Impressive, Colourful & Detailed Murals - Learn the History, Wander the Alley & Take Photos!

My mother and I visited the Balmy Alley Murals on the morning of August 2nd. We had left our Airbnb apartment early in the morning to go for a long walk through the residential side streets in the Mission District. 

We discovered many small alleyways with beautiful, colourful and unique murals on the way to the more well-known Balmy Alley Murals, as we strolled along 24th Street heading east from Mission Street. We were the only people exploring the alley during our visit which made for a peaceful and relaxed atmosphere. 

We arrived at Balmy Alley (which stemmed off from 24th Street), and I was immediately impressed by the intricate detail and vibrant colours that the murals displayed, painted on garage doors and fences in this residential back lane. We wandered down the alley and stopped at each mural to admire the beautiful street art and take photos. The murals depicted a variety of scenes which included messages and images of a political/social nature, San Francisco landmarks and street scenes, influential and historical people in San Francisco among others. The murals displayed so much culture and history. 

As we explored the alley, we met a man named Tony, who was sitting on his driveway with his Chihuahua. He was drinking a can of beer while simultaneously smoking a joint. Initially, I thought he was homeless, but I was wrong. He started chatting with us and was very friendly. He told us a little bit about himself and his background (he was a History and Cultural Arts major in college) and then shared with us the history of some of the murals and the people featured on them. He was a wealth of knowledge and it was interesting to learn from him! 

Exploring and wandering down Balmy Alley was well worth my time in San Francisco. It was a unique and slightly off the beaten path experience, and I enjoyed learning about the history of the murals.
author: Brittany T.

description:
The most famous alley way for murals! Located in the Mission very near to Humphrey Slocombe ice cream, this street is perfect for a tranquil walk-through while observing all the diverse, colorful, and powerful murals. There is usually a good amount of other people walking through and admiring the murals as well, yet the street itself is quiet, clean, and beautiful.  

The murals themselves are as visually stunning as they are culturally striking, intriguing you to observe them longer as you find new details and understand the underlying meaning. I always find something new everytime I come and it makes me wonder the history of this alleyway's creation and significance as most of the murals focus on central messages of immigration, police brutality,and civil rights for the Hispanic and Latinx communities.

It is not a long walk and is a little hidden in the neighborhood, but definitely come check it out for a cultural and emotional eye-opening afternoon stroll!
author: Kyrie S.

description:
Located in the Mission District. Parking spaces along the neighborhood.
We were the only ones walking along the alley so we had the murals to ourselves
It took us less than an hour to check this place out.
With all these murals, they all represent human rights, gentrification and Hurricane Katrina.
If you have extra time, check this place out!
See the actual beauty and meaning behind these murals!
author: Laramae E.

description: A tiny street of murals packed with so much color and history! Mostly focusing on the cultures of Southern and Central America, the Balmy Street Murals are decidedly more political than those on nearby Clarion alley. As of my May 2016 visit, the majority of murals address issues of immigration, slavery, cultural preservation, and appropriation. A single visit doesn't replace actually researching the issues, but the art is a good conversation starter for any of the multitude of issues depicted. If you're lucky enough to see one of the artists in action, talk to them! There's so much talent in this area, and so many great stories.
author: Stefany V.

description:
Some of the immigration/civil rights murals were too deep for me, but my fave was definitely Where the Wild Things Are. My friend loved the one with the juxtaposition between rich and poor. (Probably a good idea to not take us to art museums.) 

Anyway, Balmy Street kind of feels different because part of it is painted on people's garages. Feels safe during the daytime, idk about nighttime. Plus, I don't know how illuminated it would be.
author: Phoebe C.

description: I saw cool pictures on instagram so I checked it out. Not what I was expecting. Not as much art as Clairon Alley. Not really worth the trip. Stay on the other side.
author: Marcella M.

description: Murals are not uncommon in the Mission neighborhoods, but this eclectic alley contains the highest concentration.  Popping, shocking, protesting, and celebrating Latino heritage, often simultaneously, every inch of wall space is dedicated to these murals.  The artwork ranges from slightly grungy to gorgeous.  Not really sure what my friends and I were expecting as we wandered through, but this little corner of SF is an interesting free attraction that really surprised us.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Visiting Cal, I came across a mural, then 2 then I spent countless hours in my rental driving and parking and running into alley ways  ( during day light hours)
with camera in hand taking it all in. 
Beautiful, unique,tasteful works of art.
From tiles mosiacs, to stencil to old fashion spray can and bandana covering their faces. Ah-mazing.
a lot of good eats in the area too!
Ill be back!
author: Sunshine M.

description:
This street offers some great murals to spend some time looking at. There's a lot of messages here - specifically, working in the tech industry, the mural of these companies coming into SF and kicking locals out really spoke (picture to be attached).

Docking 1 star just because Clarion Alley has a lot more space for murals. Regardless,
I still recommend.
author: Dylan R.

description: Nice art work, worth taking a look at, the rest of the place I'm not so sure of, not much else to see here in this side of San Fran, but you'll enjoy this little alley, would be nice to know about the stories behind the art work!
author: Heidi I.

description:
I've lived in SF almost my entire life and never new about these murals or that SF was covered in them! It took Yelp and my search for touristy things to do to uncover these treasures!

The colors and details are just outstanding! You have to come to see them in person. Pictures do not do it justice. Best of all they are free to view!
author: Janet E.

description: I never knew this place existed, until my step son had a school project. I wasn't expecting much but was absolutely floored this is magnificent. The whole street is painted with beautiful murals, oh and I love the fact IT's FREE.
author: Alan J.

description:
I absolutely love taking photos of really interesting graffiti and murals. I find that kind of art is fascinating, as long as it's not trashy and doesn't give off the wrong message. 

I had a trip planned to Cali, and when I found this place through Yelp, I knew immediately that I had to come here. Unfortunately, I came here an hour before my flight back home, so I literally had 5 minutes to run through one alley and take as many pictures as I could. I was in awe with the amount of talent and beauty I saw everywhere. You really need to spend time at some of these murals because they give out very powerful messages and portray beautiful stories. The colors were so bright and engaging and I just find it really cool that Mission District exists. 

According to their site, Mission District began in the mid-80's as a way for artists to express their anger over human rights and political abuse in Central America. It seems to have continued leading in that direction, but with focus in America. From reading other reviews, these murals change from time to time. 

I really hope to come back to San Fran soon, and when I do, this will be one of the first places I will come back to. Next time, I will stay a bit longer and check out the neighborhood around Mission District.
author: Natasha R.

description: Awesome block w every garage door painted in a mural, typically reflecting the gentrification and ousting of the local community in favor of the rich. Quite powerful art that must be seen. Also, some murals dedicated to saving water are moving and a stark reminder of our limited resources.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Don't miss all the great local art !! You should experience this because:

1. Unlike most of what's for sale on Valencia St., It was made locally, not in China.
2. You'll get a chance to walk the 24th St. corridor - as others have said and I agree, it's the true "heart" of the Mission.
3. In doing so, you'll bookmark all sorts of bars, cafes etc. to visit on your next trip.
4. You can add some really cool backgrounds to your smartphone.
5. Kids, babies, dogs, cigars - -  bring em all, no prob.
6. Two legendary ice cream haunts within a 15 minute walk.
7. No charge! And, no waiting in line for this SF art gallery !!!
author: John H.

description: Wanted to something different for this trip to the city for the kids, we have done all the tourist things and boat tours, so was seeking something new. I found out on Yelp about Balmy Street Murals and though this might be cool my daughter is into art so thought we are going to go check it out. We took Bart down to 24th st and then walked up to Balmy St, along the way we started to see the murals painted everywhere along the way, then we got to Balmy street, which is really more like an alley way and slowly walked our way down, each painting tells a story, every one done with vivid color. We enjoyed our little walk down Balmy Street, even showed my pops a street he didn't know about, and this has been his city for years. It's a great find to go see if you have the time!
author: Monica O.

description:
ART: Check.
CULTURE: Check.
FREE: Check. Check.

I had a friend visiting and wanted to take him to the NOT so touristy places and came across Balmy St here on Yelp. 

We took our time admiring and wondering about the stories these murals told. Took awesome pics and then went to go get some food nearby. My son, (3 then), enjoyed it too!

Worth coming back to: CHECK!
author: Janis M.

description:
Absolutely beautiful.  We stayed with friends in the Mission, and while they were at work during the day, we had plenty of time to explore the neighborhood. We didn't take the Precita Eyes Tour, but are considering it for next visit.

It's much easier to photograph the murals when you're not pressed for time, so plan accordingly.  I used a panoramic photo app for some shots, and my still camera for others. Each method highlighted different interesting elements.  When we went, a lot of flowering vines were in bloom, and draped themselves around the edges of the murals. I also photographed the artist info (usually near the bottom or corner of the work) so that I could look up their other work when I got home.

It IS an alley. There are some trash cans. People might want to get out of their garage. Occasionally someone uses the alley instead of a toilet. These things happen. Watch your step and enjoy the beauty that these artists have taken the time to create (and maintain). It's like they've painted a bit of their soul for you to consider.
author: AD J.

description: I felt very safe walking through here during the daytime as there were a few other people in the alley as well. I wish I had some explaination to the murals though.
author: Lemon C.

description:
First of all, how can you not like art?  Secondly, how can you not like art that has meaning behind it?  

Be prepared to have interesting encounters here.  My first experience wasn't the best, as I came by myself on a morning weekday and was followed around by a homeless/mentally compromised individual that seemed tweaked out on drugs and trying to offer to carry my backpack several times (uh huh...).  The second time I brought someone here with me and we were given an extremely long lecture (15 minutes....) on the Spanish Mexican war.  My third trip through the original painters of one of a thirty year old mural was being restored and that was soooo cool to see. 

So go.  You'll find some interesting people watching at a minimum.
author: Cassandra A.

description:
I had some extra time to spare while walking around the Mission and looked to yelp for some advice. I'm SO happy I found the reviews for the Balmy Alley Murals while perusing.

What an absolute gem. This small street of murals encompassed more culture, emotion and heritage than the entire rest of the Mission District combined! I spent a long time slowly meandering down the street, admiring each mural, and trying to truly understand the story behind the art. Not only were the murals beautiful, they were powerful, inspiring, and some were even tear inducing.

I made my way down to Clarion Alley after finishing my walk and loved the differences between the two alleys. Visiting both streets is an absolute must if you're in the area!
author: Julie B.

description:
Make sure you stop by the Precita Eyes Mural visitor center to grab a map of all the fantastic murals in the Mission. But if you don't want to pay the $5 Map fee, you can pretty much just walk up and down 24th St trying to find all of them. One of the more interesting ones is of course the Balmy Street Murals - its an alley off of 24th St. 

If you're into portrait photography, make sure you stop in front of the turquoise colored and japanese flower themed murals on 24th. 

The street is also great if you're hungry - you can stop by the famous El Farolito for a super Burrito or any great mexican fare.

The original Philz coffee is here as well - great ambiance and freshly brewed coffee.
author: Henry W.

description:
Reasons why you should check out the famous Balmy Street!
- Very unique pieces of art 
- FREE 
- You can touch the art and take flash photography! 
- culture

Reasons why you shouldnt check out Balmy Street...
NONE

Enough said..
author: Jackie R.

description:
I knew about the colorful murals in the Mission, but I actually didn't know there was one block devoted to some of the more audacious ones until Jamie W. and I were strolling to Humphry Slocombe for our virginal visit anticipating some good, sweet lickin'. Jamie pointed out the alley as we were speed-walking by.

Well, I knew I had to see them since I'm always looking for a good story to write as the San Francisco Travel Examiner. Sure enough, I did write that article, and it turned out to be the most read travel article that week on the Examiner site. So instead of repeating it here, click on this link to read about my brief visit and see the wondrous murals I saw in the slide show ...http://www.examiner.com/x-515-SF-Travel-Examiner~y2009m5d5-Colorful-Mission-District-Murals-to-fill-your-Cinco-De-Mayo
author: Ed U.

description:
Gorgeous, thoughtful, thought-provoking wall art. Changes and evolves over the years as older murals deteriorate and new ones are added. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_cOXVjvweYYDsfcrSRaZug?select=6-jt-uWVu4NHmnvAsqKt0w). Worth visiting--it's a cool feeling to be totally surrounded by creative expression. 

Highly recommend coming with a tour guide (talk to Precita Eyes: http://www.yelp.com/biz/precita-eyes-mural-arts-center-san-francisco#query:mural%20alley) who can provide insight and background information about each of the murals and many of the artists.
author: Kristin M.

description: Loved the artistry and character of this neighborhood and the street. It depicts the unique character of the district which is still struggling to maintain its humble, working class identity with the onslaught of gentrification. Very creative.
author: Be A.

description:
ART IS THE INTERNATIONAL LANGUAGE THAT MAKES US STOP, THINK AND SMILE/LAUGH/CRY. I happen across this alley while driving a friend thru the area recently and hiked back to get pixs of something else I saw, but then stumbled across this alley. I was in a hurry as someone was waiting for me two blocks ago but if in th area (or not),YOU MUST see these gorgeous murals. Any description is beyond belief...  as they/we say in spanish: hay que ver (you need to see it yourself - git your butt outa da house now and SEE it).

PHOTOGRAPHICALLY SPEAKING: Take a wide-angle if you have one, anything else is just too "long" to capture these vivid colored murals. A tripod isn't necessary unless you're got earthquake-hands. Don't use flash. A gray-sky day without shadows is perfect and watch your time of day in preventing shadows across these murals resulting in partially dark/bright areas due to under- and over-exposures. Go with time on your hands so you can ENJOY the art after snapping it. Respect the artists and if any firmas (signatures) are shown,please include it in your images. Disfrutes/enJoY!!!

UPDATE: One should view and enjoy these murals and other nearby murals during the day. BE AWARE of the people and situations/events around you. Have a third eye as you view these and be sure their is an "exit" hideaway no matter where you are. Not trying to scare others away, but things are sadly and undeservingly changing in the Mission, so be careful!!

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2011%2F05%2F08%2FEDR01J5UIB.DTL  

if in the future this article is not archived and thus no longer available, email/msg me and i'll send you a copy; i'll save it on my laptop.
author: Tony L.

description:
I was so happy to accidentally find this place on my way to Humphrey Slocombe's today. My wedding photographer had taken gorgeous shots here before, and I had always wanted to see it for myself.

On first glance, it might look like just another mural. But as you stroll down the brick-laden street of Balmy, the art seems to leap off the walls (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_cOXVjvweYYDsfcrSRaZug?select=TimZ_Luuti7G4mGBgjFdtw). Not only are the colors vibrant, but some of the art is actually 3-dimensional (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/_cOXVjvweYYDsfcrSRaZug?select=p6F8rAhc_0SWdSlWZDwOOw), which helps to mask some of the more industrial elements of this street (namely, the unattractive metal screens on the windows).

It's truly a Mission gem. I'm partial to it because it represents families like mine. My parents came to the United States from Mexico in the early 70's, at a time when the Mission district became home to lots of Latino families. Although the murals are not limited to latin-american subjects, it represents an artistic and political movement that I'm proud of.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Do yourself a favor and check this alley out. 

http://flickr.com/photos/calmenda/sets/72157603458343094/

Take your time, look at the murals and think about the message. 

The murals are beautiful and powerful. Most of the murals center around latin-american issues.

If you ever want to venture off the beaten path, this is the place to go. 

Who needs the classics when you have grassroots art in your own backyard?

:-)
author: Carlos A.

description:
Likes: Lots of murals painted on the backyard walls or garages of houses along the street.  Cars can drive through.  My favorite one was the mural with the giant transformer robot, teddy bears and doggies in the air and what looked like a Scooby-doo.  Plus there's a good ice cream place right across the street :P

Dislikes: Car driving really close by when you're walking through the street.  Just stand to the side.
author: Karen M.

description: Yelper Jess C said it best as Balmy Street Murals is- A Must See in SF. Exquisite artwork with vibrant colors and it's all FREE! Can't get better than that.
author: Irene Y.

description: The Mission is known for its artistic murals. However, Balmy alley is a fantastic find with the clever local art. It's amazing that it is part of people's homes, unlike some of the other murals that are part of businesses and public locations. Many of the murals have some sort of message and theme, including the gentrification of the old San Francisco neighborhoods that give it the character that they are known for. Take a closer look the next time you're there!
author: Trang H.

description: This is a random alleyway of garages and homes painted with murals. It was a great place to pick up some local flavor, admire art, and learn about some of the social issues that matter to those who live in this area.
author: Stacy G.

description: South of the Border meets Wall Street USA with artistic expression oozing at the seems.  Freedom of speach has never been so well utilized at this mural series.
author: Mr B.

description: Found this recommendation on yelp and had to review it.  We recently did a family overnight in the city.  We did Union square, North Beach , House of Air, IMAX theatre, Lyon St. steps and the Murals.  The Murals easily ranked right at the top of the list.  It isn't always easy to please a 16 & 11 year old, but this was great!  Everyone dropped in - it was a calming, promoted great conversation about social justice, racism, economic disparity,etc  and added a great artistic and cultural experience to the trip.
author: Karen C.

description: Awesome place to absorb the art and history of the neighborhood. LOVED IT!
author: Angela L.

description:
This is definitely an awesome alley!! Most of the houses in the alley are painted with beautiful, colorful murals of the most random things. One house had a mural of Max sailing in the ocean from Where the Wilds Thing Are. Another mural was of a woman giving birth to a child. They are all beautiful and probably symbolic in their own way...though, I like to believe some paintings are meant to just be pretty.

I think the houses without murals need to get on it stat.
author: Margaret R.

description:
A must-see in SF.

This is an alley with colorful, meaningful, culturally-relevant works of art, many related to Latin-American issues. and FREE. Honestly can't get better than this.

My favorites were the tribute to AIDS victims, mention of future women leaders, robots, where the wild things are, poignant note from man separated by distance from wife and child, and Michael Jackson. I can't wait to come back next time to see new murals.
author: Jess C.

description:
Balmy Alley has a life of its own. 

The original block parties location has become a famous Mission District attraction. Balmy Alley features colorful murals stemming from Hispanic roots. 

Creative. Original. Evolving.
author: Jack C.

description:
Compared to Clarion, Balmy is in a calmer setting, but both are absolutely wonderful and well worth the walk through them. Just about every available bit of wall space is covered in beautiful pictures. 

When it comes to choosing a favorite mural in either alley, as Drew Barrymore might say in "Ever After," "I could no sooner choose a favorite star in the heavens." 

Balmy also has the added bonus of being in close proximity to Humphry Slocombe. It's nice to get a couple scoops, escape the crowds vying for seats, and take a leisurely walk down Balmy.
author: Christine A.

description:
THIS PLACE ROCKS!!

One of the few redeeming features that tell the story of what The Mission used to be!

I've gotta take my students here to see the history  through art!
author: Gina H.

description: Really cool alley mural art. If you're on a budget and you like urban exploration, check this alleyway out. Lots of cool art.
author: Amy J.

description:
If I were able to get my lazy butt out of bed earlier on the weekends, this is where you'd find me every Sunday morning with some good company and a fresh cup of coffee. It's an awesome date trip or a pretty rad way to show out of town guests a slice of San Francisco.

As is, I've only successfully made it here once "early" in the morning. And that was definitely a 5-star experience. All the other times it's been in the mid to late afternoon, and many of those times it's filled with hipster kids from Humphrey Slocombe and tourists wanting me to take pictures of them with the murals.

I guess I can't really fault the murals for my inability to mobilize at 9 am, or for the fact that they're such an awesome thing to see that they're being put in a lot of the SF guide books now, but I wish they didn't get so crowded. Learn from my mistakes: go early!
author: Monica C.

description: This is such a beautiful attraction in San Francisco - and the best part of all is its FREE!!!
author: Mary M.

description: Consider it a free outdoor art gallery.  Having a guide from San Francisco City Guides (http://www.sfcityguides.org/index.html) explain the history and meaning of art helped me appreciate them more.  Recommend checking City Guides for the next free tour or stopping by Precita Eyes Mural Arts and Visitor Center (http://www.yelp.com/biz/SRmbFOdZypTh6WAX8aVgcg) on 24th Street prior to viewing the murals to enhance your experience.
author: トモ T.

description:
Oooh, definitely worth visiting! It's a really enjoyable and interesting alternative to most other city walks. The murals are super colorful and just plain nice to look at. You can spend many minutes looking at every mural because of all the details in each piece.

It's emptiest in the morning hours, so it would make a nice post-morning coffee walk.
author: Sonia M.

description:
Yelp suggestions inspired me to check out Balmy Street. I needed a good "staycation" activity for a Labor Day Weekend in the city. Balmy Street offered a great place for walking and exploring the Mission. This unique alley is lined with colorful murals painted along fences, buildings, and doors. 

There are a variety of styles and images. On one end, you'll find images from childrens' stories like "Where the Wild Things Are" and transformer cartoons. There are also several political, cause-related murals as well as others that are purely for aesthetics. Photos (attached) capture the experience best.

Tips -

Bring a camera!
Walk along 24th from Mission to Balmy Street to see more murals
author: Heather W.

description:
Balmy Alley is a place I discovered soon after moving to San Francisco, and gratefully so.

On that first visit, I was so moved by the art, the variety of content depicted, the variety of visual styles, the very obvious artistry and warmth and anger and passion emanating from the alley - and I feel it every time I go back. I've brought friends, I've gone to watch a new mural in progress, I've even performed here for an open class assignment.

To be perfectly honest, it's not a spot I visit frequently, and it's comforting just to know that it's there. Occasionally when walking down 24th St I'll sneak a quick peek, and I feel reassured that as long as places like this exist, we still have some common humanity within our grasp. How wonderful it must be to live in one of those houses!
author: Sam S.

description: I've been living in the Mission for little over a year now and I never tire of taking a slow stroll down Balmy.
author: Priscilla M.

description:
the difference between graffiti and murals is?

murals have permission.


i'm down for street art, i've done my fare share of drawing/tagging while i was in class in high school, but i've never really had the chance to take it out into the streets. this is all to say, i'm a fan.

walking around balmy alley and just taking in the art is one thing, i would also like to recommend getting a guided tour. take it whichever way you would prefer, enjoy it on your own or take the time to learn a little history behind the work, i just hope that you do it.

Teacher Tip: i discovered this place while looking for places to take my students to for a field trip. i recommend it.  just be prepared. have a plan on which places you want to see. so go before you go. it's lots of walking. plan stops along the way, for food, for bathroom and of course for fun. 

until next time

cheers!
author: Jerico P.

description:
This small alley in the Mission District is home to some of San Francisco's best murals! 

I would suggest taking a leisurely stroll down the alley to admire the murals. Some have very strong historical and political messages. If you're interested in learning more about the murals or the muralists you can take a guided walking tour from Precita Eyes
http://www.yelp.com/biz/SRmbFOdZypTh6WAX8aVgcg

Balmy alley manages to capture the culture essence and the sense of community that makes the mission so unique.
author: Lori K.

description:
Between the 24th and 25th streets and just north of Garfield Square sits one of my favorite little blocks in all of the city. Actually more of an alleyway, this brick-paved street runs behind mostly private garages and paved patios, but with one very cool twist: nearly all of the fences, garages and walls are covered with colorful murals!

Really, it's something you just have to see. Some murals feature recognizable characters or scenes, while others seem to be completely original works of art. And if you go during the right time of the year, the ubiquitous red flower vines just might be in bloom. One last thing: don't try to drive down this street. It's best to enjoy the murals on foot or bike.
author: Dave K.

description: What a fantastic display of character! You'll be trying to figure out how to take pictures of them all. This is a must-see for any San Francisco visiter, then you can get some awesome authentic Mexican while you're in the Mission, too.
author: Pam F.

description: Beautiful! It's definitely a place to come to and if you are a photographer, definitely a place to shoot.  This isn't your typical graffiti in the ghetto- it's art. Everything has a meaning, every mural has some history.  It's a must go if you're visiting SF, and it's free to boot!
author: Meena N.

description:
Balmy Street Murals are a must see if you are visiting The Mission. The murals are full color, creative, offer a huge variety, and many have messages. 

The street is short and you can walk through it very quickly- or take your time and explore. I took many photos on this street and was happy I made the trip to view it.

FYI's~
* Photos of the murals make great screen savers :) 
* The street is more like an alley
* Easy to miss if you are not looking
* Close to Taqueria Vallarta- right off of 24th
author: Natalie W.

description: Amazing stuff and hey, it's free!  You'll see murals all over the Mission, however, Balmy street tells a nice story and each mural has it's own unique story.  It's great to visit this area during summer, especially when they close the streets during Sunday walk the streets events.  Keep in mind that you're walking through an alley and these are painted behind garages of residents, but thats the beauty of it.  Just a different perspective.
author: Sunny C.

description: The murals are even nicer than the ones in Clarion Alley. I went for the first time with one of the guides from the Precita Eyes Mural Center, and it was definitely worth it. Also, don't forget to check the rejoice mural at the side of the building, will definitely brighten your day!
author: Abel M.

description:
This is a great destination in the Mission and a good excuse to stroll down 24th and check everything on that street out as well.  Put it on the weekend itinerary for any and all of your visitors who have the good sense to not think that North Beach, Union Square, and the Haight are the city's must-sees.  

The murals are very well maintained, bright and vibrant, many (but not all) in a style familiar to anyone who has traveled in Central America.  Some of the most memorable are scenes depicting massacres and struggle from the civil war years in El Salvador and Guatemala.  Some of the murals, in turn, explicitly make the connection between the violence in those countries and the migration of Central Americans to the Mission.  An even-more-cynical-than-I reviewer or two has made snarky comments about the alley (maybe "too many people know about it now" or some bullshit), but at the end of the day these are unique and meaningful artistic representations of the history of the local community.  Very worth your time.
author: Josh C.

description:
If an America's Next Top Model photo shoot is what you seek, Balmy Street Murals.

If trying to look like a really cool local who knows all of the free, unique experiences San Francisco has to offer, Balmy Street Murals.

If trying to impress an unwashed, brooding, underweight, sexy art student is your desire, Balmy Street Murals.

If you seek self-reflection and to ponder existence, Balmy Street Murals.

If in need of a conversation starter, Balmy Street Murals.

If drawn to psychedellics, Balmy Street Murals.

If in San Francisco, Balmy Street Murals.
author: Rachael S.

description: Very, very intriguing and impressive murals that are worth the find. Located on an inviting And humble street, homeowners were touching up and adding to their artwork. A great education of the city's history and flavor, told from the Mission. Visit during the day, bring your camera, and take your time!
author: Alice W.

description: It's a walking city in a walking neighborhood and this is something you want to stumble upon and stroll through. It's the corrazon de Mission districto (true heart of this district), but people live here so pay your respects.
author: James-Jimm P.

description:
This was one of the first places I visited when I moved to San Francisco in 2004.  I think that Balmy Street is one of those things which just epitomizes the San Francisco experience.

I was only there once - and, WHY is that?  I don't know - however, the impression the vibrant artwork which runs between 24th and 25th street made on me has stuck with me all this time.

I've got to make time to get back there - it's wonderful.
author: Kate R.

description:
Although I often despise having to walk around, take the bus, and work in it, I love the Mission.  All of the things I despise--except the hipsters--are also all of the things that contribute to its greatness.  But then there are some things in the Mission that contribute to its greatness that I don't despise.  And the murals are some of those things, and the ones on Balmy Street are especially some of those things.

OK, it's 4:24 a.m., and I just wrote some of my least elegant sentences ever on Yelp.  In any case, I love these murals, partially because they're weird and just in a random alley and partially because I know two of the muralists (sort of) and partially because I spent some dollars at Precita Eyes (I think) for a map of the murals, a map I haven't used in two years.
author: John S.

description: my friend and i had looked at a "city guide" booklet that was in our hotel room and i had seen a section on really great murals in the mission district and wanted to check it out. our friend that lives in SF drove us to mission where we parked and walked around and as shady as it sounds, we walked down random alleys but to find really awesome murals, most painted on garage doors. out of all the alleys we walked down, i think this one was my favorite. each mural had a specific meaning and feeling behind it and just made each one so special. this alley particularly felt inspirational with emotions of pain, sacrifice, success, and overcoming hardships to name a few. each one makes you stop and think. i really feel like the murals in the mission district are a hidden gem of SF and would definitely recommend checking it out, especially if you're an art fan.
author: Lina O.

description: If you love vibrant colors, history, and art--then you have to visit Balmy Alley.  It's beautiful.
author: Jean C.

description:
History lesson on the Mission distirict. Easy free mural tour. Classic San Francisco. I practically grew up in this alley. Then go to La Victoria pick up some pan dulces and or head to La Palma and score some pupusas or tortillas. 

If tempted, wait until Dia De Los Muertos (Nov. 2nd) and score some even better sights with day of the dead alters at near by galleries and pan de muerto (day of the dead bread).
author: Niki M.

description: I am from South India and been living in bay area for past 6+ years. I have been fortunate as my aunt works as tour guide for San Francisco and has given me a personal ride to this street. She explained the artwork, history of murals, meaning behind each mural and how the places around this street evolved over many years. It is a fantastic street where you can find artwork at its best. Once you see this, you would then start looking at each mural (big or small) with great interest. Yay, I loved it!!! Don't miss to visit  a store close by where the artists also teach about how to paint a mural and sell some good souvenirs
author: Raj T.

description:
this alley should be on all the "to see lists" of San Francisco, its amazing small alley of contemporary murals in great nighborhood of mission when you can after this spot to walk around to see more murals in every corner.

this is my favorite spot in mission
author: Bin K.

description:
This place is one of the reasons I love living where I do.  Good on you, San Francisco.

My suggestion for a great afternoon, especially if you're trying to impress an out-of-towner with Local Color: walk down Balmy Street towards 25th, then take a right and go have tasty treats at Mission Pie.  Hell yes.
author: Jess L.

description:
It's late at night, and we have this tradition that we take our visiting niece and nephew to a surprise place every night. Tonight is Murals night. We start with Balmy street. First find the place. Then find parking. Then walk with two teenagers through this unlikely district, asking for direction to groups of people chatting in the street. They hadn't expected this side of San Francisco. Already they are mesmerized. But wait until we get to Balmy Street. We do it twice back and forth, trying to figure out the murals in the darkness. It's like telling stories around a campfire in the wild late at night.
Later, our niece will say that that night was the best of the whole stay.
author: Elsa T.

description:
One of the more colorful alleyways in SF, as opposed to the usual foul-smelling crack & urine alleys. 

A must-see!
author: Trixie J.

description: If you are a tourista, if you are a local... if you are wondering why you are looking at this review on mobile yelp...it's because you should go.  Whether you haven't gone for years and meant to, or you are looking for part of the real art and culture of the city... take the brief jaunt and enjoy some of the amazing art that peers out from blind alleys and lonely corners... and get some semblance of the vibration and true depth of character that this city has to offer.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
This and Clarion alley are by far the best place for street art in San Francisco and maybe even US. Balmy st is the older site and you can find guided tours from Precita Eyes.

Clarion is newer and the art has more anger in it. Don't be put off by the stink. And don't be scared. It is safe - at the end of the road is the local police station.

For a link to some high quality photos of the murals and more local flavor of these two streets: 

http://locomotoring.net/2008/07/24/mural-hunting-in-mission-district/


You will be happy to note that SFO is one of the best cities for mural art. Even Diego Rivera (http://diegorivera.com/index.php) painted murals here. 

Sometimes my out of town guests do get put off by the down to earth Mission district but for locals this is the place to go. So if you are an adventurous visitor, want to do what the local do, please visit Mission after the more obvious piers, north beach, china town and the union square. And if you are at Mission, you can't but not see the murals.

For a more complete trip of the Mission area, read on :

http://locomotoring.net/2008/12/29/three-hours-at-mission-district-of-san-francisco/
author: Mishti D.

description: This public art display is fascinating to see, feel and grok. The murals are powerfully raw, and some amused me, some punched me in the gut. I will walk the one-block alley again and again in the future. Balmy Street is an alley of fences and garage doors, with about 90% of the paintable surfaces done in murals. Some depict farm workers, some depict Native Americans, some depict metaphysical mysteries. One in particular was stunning to me: a woman spread out like a biology lab dissected frog giving birth. Primitive and powerful. There is a Taqueria at the end of the block (Vallarta Taqueria) on 24th Street if you want to get a bite to eat.
author: Theo J.

description: Great guerilla-style graffiti and latin immigrant-themed murals with a message located in an alleyway off 24th street. It's a fascinating open-air street art exhibit with attitude that features murals laced with some historical and social meaning and some with reckless artistic abandon. All done by passionate, talented and socially aware artists with fervor and a meaningful voice.
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm an SF native..and so ashamed to say that I never really explored everything the Mission had to offer until this year. Now I can't get enough..of the food, drink, culture, and now the art. 

Who can justify paying $12 for a museum entrance fee when you can see the best art in SF for freezy?! I recently inherited the bfs castaway DSLR when he upgraded so I needed a quick lesson and some tips. What a great place for a self-guided photography walking tour! Even though it's less smelly than Clarion alley, there'll still be times when you wished you were upwind....but it's worth every nasal flaring, gag provoking whiff.
author: Emily W.

description: Beautofull. I love the murals! I hope they continue to be developed throughout the city. They're true art and a constant source of inspiration!
author: Andrew C.

description: A drive through museum and essential stop during a day of guiding out of town guests.
author: Mike O.

description: So haard to find this street. i walked and walked and the visitors I was taking to the place became kinda angry with me for so much walking. But the murals were worth it. Advice: just read something in advance, in order to fully appreciate them.
author: Ioana D.
